abstract.p: Letter from Elana J Weinstein, prompted by May 10 Workplace article on photos people keep on their office desk, says many office environments are not yet accepting enough to have homosexual or lesbian bring in picture of his or her partner

block.p: Re ''Judging People by the Pictures They Keep'' (Workplace section, May 10):
You ask, ''If one picture is worth a thousand words, what is the meaning of the dozens of photos of spouse and children on display in your manager's office?''
Re ''Judging People by the Pictures They Keep'' (Workplace section, May 10):
You ask, ''If one picture is worth a thousand words, what is the meaning of the dozens of photos of spouse and children on display in your manager's office?''
More often than not, it means that the manager has an office advantage -- one of heterosexual privilege.
While in theory everyone should feel free to bring in photographs of significant others, it is very common for gay men and lesbians to feel reluctant to do so.
I have the liberty to display a picture of my boyfriend without hesitation; some gay men and lesbians are not as lucky.
Sadly, many office environments are not yet accepting enough to have a gay man bring his partner to the holiday office party, or even to hang a picture of him in his cubicle.
ELANA J. WEINSTEIN New York, May 10, 2000
